Department: Mayor's Office of New Urban Mechanics
Description: Rebecca Williams Harvard Kennedy School’s?Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: This request for contract documents related to all smart city technology purchased or in operation by this agency for the period from 1/1/2015 - present. These smart city technologies include any contract document that contains: - The terms “smart city.” - Internet of Things (IoT) technologies (such as connected sensors, lights, and meters that collect data). - Mobility data collection (such as “intelligent transportation system" or rideshare or cell-phone location data agreements). - Video technologies (such as “closed- circuit television,” traffic, security, or streetlight cameras). Specifically, I am requesting contract documents to which this agency and any smart city technology vendor are parties. These materials include: - Any lists of related contracts. - Any contracts, including any pilot, proof-of-concept, and public-private partnership agreements. - Any data purchase, licensing, or exchange agreements. - Any privacy policies or terms of use/service. - Any vendor distribution lists for related requests for proposals. If another office would be a more appropriate destination for this request, I would be happy to forward this request according to your direction. If additional agencies or jurisdictions would also have responsive or associated materials, the provision of the names of those entities would also be appreciated. These records will be used to inform research on “smart city system” best practices as part of Harvard Kennedy School’s?Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs’ Technology and Public Purpose (TAPP) Project that culminates in May 2020. To accommodate this deadline and inclusion in analysis please expedite this request so that it is filled by February 2020. Because of our not-for-profit status and the fact that this request is about a matter in the public interest, I request a fee waiver. If you have any questions or would like to discuss narrowing the request, please contact me directly at rebeccawilliams@hks.harvard.edu or ?(857) 400-0323. I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. Sincerely, Rebecca Williams

Maggie Mulvihill Boston University School of Journalism Dear Sgt. Boyle: Pursuant to the state public records law, M.G.L., ch. 66, sec. 10; c.4, sec. 7: c.26 and any other applicable state or federal laws or regulations, BU requests access to the following: - all records related to earnings paid to civilian and sworn personnel assigned to any community service office in the city. I request this information from Jan. 1, 2019 to present. We request this information in electronic format. If any fields or records are deleted or redacted, please provide a detailed explanation of the exemption under the laws your office relies on to justify the deletion or redaction. Also please provide all documentation necessary to load and analyze this data, including the record layout for each table, field descriptions and electronic copies of the codes. As you are aware, the state Public Records Law does not allow a blanket exemption for public records but instead requires the custodian of the records to justify withholding any or all parts of a record by the application of narrowly- defined exemptions. When exempt information is intertwined with non-exempt information, the non-exempt portions are subject to disclosure once the exempt portions are deleted. If any or all or any part of this request is denied, please cite the specific statutory exemption(s) which you believe justifies your refusal to release the information and inform me of your agency's administrative appeals procedures available to BU under the statute(s). The law requires your agency provide a response to this request within 10 days by either denying the request or making an offer to provide the requested materials. I request an expedited response to this request and a waiver of all fees, as allowed for by the state statute. The public's right to access to records maintained by public agencies such as yours may be enforced by court order of mandamus. The records I request are very specific and narrowly defined and memorialize the kind of routine business for which the public has an interest. If you have any questions regarding this request, please don't hesitate to contact me at 617-686- 7038. Thank you in advance for your help. [SPR21/0573]

Bruce Barnett DLA Piper LLP (US) On behalf of my client, Boston Medical Center Corporation, I am writing in connection with the Menino Additions and Renovations project located at 840 Harrison Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts (the “Project”). I respectfully request that you make available for inspection and copying, pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Act, M.G.L. c. 66, § 10, the specific documents identified below concerning the Project. Pursuant to the statute, please make available not only all documents that constitute public records (as that term is defined by statute) but also, where a record includes one or more portions that constitute a public record and one or more portions that constitute a non-public record, all segregable portions that constitute public records. This request utilizes the following definitions: 1. “Document” is used in the broadest sense possible including, without limitation, correspondence, memoranda, notes, plans, meeting minutes, agreements, and any tape or other type of memory record associated with computers and data processing, including e-mail messages and their attachments. 2. “Communication” means any transmission, transfer, or exchange of information (in the form of facts, ideas, inquiries, or otherwise) by any means, including, without limitation, any written, printed, typed, electronic, photographed, recorded, or otherwise reproduced communication or representation. 3. “Reflecting” or “relating to,” mean referring to, summarizing, reflecting, referencing, constituting, containing, embodying, pertaining to, involved with, mentioning, consisting of, comprising, showing, commenting on, evidencing, describing, or otherwise discussing the subject matter. 4. “NFPA 241” means the Standard for Safeguarding Construction, Alteration, and Demolition Operations by the National Fire Protection Association. The requests are as follows: 1. Documents and communications reflecting or relating to NFPA 241 violations for Suffolk Construction Company, Inc. related to the Project. 2. Documents and communications reflecting or relating to NFPA 241 violations for Suffolk Construction Company, Inc.’s subcontractors on the Project, including the following subcontractors: a. Cox Engineering Company b. Liberty Construction Services, LLC c. Limbach Company LLC d. J.C. Cannistraro, LLC e. Sullivan & McLaughlin Companies, Inc. f. Sweeney Drywall Finishes Corp. 3. Documents and communications reflecting or relating to NFPA 241 violations for Code Red Consultants LLC related to the Project. CiovO\

Curtis Gilbert American Public Media I am researching the hiring and training of officers at police departments around the country, and I am writing to request records from your department documenting the following: A. Demographic records on police academy applicants, recruits and hires 1. Data on the number of applicants to the police academy each year (2010-2020) broken down by demographic group, (e.g., number of white male applicants in 2011, number of white female applicants in 2012, number of black male applicants, etc.) 2. Data on the number of recruits admitted to the academy each year (2010-2020) broken down by demographic group. 3. Data on the number of graduates from the police academy each year (2010- 2020) broken down by demographic group. 4. Data on the number of officers completing their field training each year (2010-2020) broken down by demographic group. 5. Overall number of sworn officers in the department (current) broken down by demographic group. 6. Overall number of sworn officers (current) holding the rank of sergeant or higher, broken down by demographic group. Ideally, I would like records dating back to 2010 as outlined above. However, if older records are not readily available, I would be open to narrowing the request to whatever range of dates is readily available. Records responsive to this section may be contained in the database the department (or municipality) uses to track human resources-related information. Courts have generally held that databases and the information within them are public records and that querying a database does not constitute the creation of a new record. Center for Investigative Reporting v. U.S. Dep't. of Justice, Case No. 18-17356, 2020 WL 7064638 (9th Cir. 2020). B. Records related to certain police academy procedures In addition to the statistical records described in section A, I would separately like to request a few records related to the policies and discipline practices employed by the academy. 1. The most recent edition of the police academy manual, handbook or similar document(s) laying out the rules or expectations for academy recruits 2. Records, including videos and written documentation, documenting to the use of physical discipline (e.g. requiring recruits to run laps, do sit-ups, push-ups, planks or other exercises as punishment for infractions) dated 2018-present 3. Records, including videos, documenting uniform or firearm inspection drills dated 2018-present If you have any questions about the records I am requesting, please don’t hesitate to contact me. If some responsive records are more easily located than others, I would ask that you provide them on a rolling production schedule, rather than waiting for all the records to be assembled. Thank you for your time and attention. CiovO\

Arlene Once Cetrulo LLP Counsellors At Law Re: FOIA Request Date of Accident: July 25, 2020 Dear Sir/Madam: This is a request pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, M.G.L. Ch. 66 10. I request copies of all documents in the possession or control of the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office related to the July 25, 2020 incident involving Jamal M. Leary at 8th Street and West Broadway, South Boston, Massachusetts. These documents include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) The logs, runsheets, call recordings, and other documents and materials generated as a result of, or in connection with the incident. (2) All photographs taken, generated or otherwise obtained during, in connection with, and/or as a result of the incident. (3) All reports, citations, notes, memorandum, correspondence, email or other paperwork and/or documents generated or otherwise obtained during, in connection with, and/or as a result of the incident, including but not limited to the Accident Reconstruction Report ( including video footage) and all other reports prepared by or for Sergeant Detective Thomas Barrett and any reports prepared by Homicide Unit / Fatal Collision Investigative Team, Autopsy OCME # 2020-10397 attended by Police Officer Derek Jefferson, VD 107, assigned to the Crime Scene Response Unit and all reports prepared by Luke Goldworm (DA's Crime Strategies Bureau. (4) All evidence taken from the scene relative to the incident. (5) All statements taken from any person associated with the incident. (6) All 91 1 calls, transcripts and/or tapes generated as a result of, or in connection of the incident. (7) All video taken from the scene relative to the incident, including but not limited to, dash cam footage from the police car, body cam footage from the police officer involved, body cam footage from any responding officers, and traffic surveillance video. (8) All toxicology reports and/or blood alcohol reports obtained from anyone involved in the incident. (9) If for some reason not included in 1- 8 above, any documents, photograph, sketch or other material generated or otherwise obtained during, in connection with, and/or as a result of the incident. Denial of Cetrulo LLP's FOIA request would be unlawful as (1) conduct occurring in plain view is unprotected; (2) only "highly personal and intimate" matters are worthy of protection; (3) disclosures of even the most "highly personal and intimate" matters are acceptable so long as they serve a countervailing interest. See Schlesinger v. Merrill Lynch, 567 N.E.2d 912 (Mass 1991); Bratt v. Int' 1 Bus. Mach. corp. 467 N.E. 2d 126 (Mass. 1984); cefalu v. Globe Newspaper co., 391 N.E. 2d 935 (Mass. App. Ct. 1979); Stanton v. Metro corp., 357 F. supp. 2d 369 (D. Mass. 2005). By appearing in a public place, one "doffs the cloak of privacy which the law protects. " Cefalu v. Globe Newspaper Co., 391 N.E. 2d 935 (Mass. App. Ct. 1979) (defendant published a photo that depicted the plaintiff waiting in line for public benefits). One relinquishes their right to privacy when in public or in the presence of others who owe no duty of confidentiality. Dasey v. Anderson, 304 F.3d 148, 152-54 (1st Cir. 2002). (holding use of video footage of defendant police officer smoking marijuana was not an invasion of privacy as the filming was in public). Public conduct is not limited to public spaces; it can also occur on private property. French v. United Parcel Serv., Inc., 2F. Supp. 2d (D. Mass. 1998) (holding the plaintiffs acts done in the privacy of his own home were not entitled to personal privacy protection as those with no duty of confidentiality witnessed them). Only matters that are "highly personal and intimate" are covered under the invasion of privacy statute. Brail v. Int' I Bus. Mach. Corp. 467 N.E. 2d 126 (Mass. 1984) (finding images of nude mentally ill patient

Mark Walker The New York Times This is a public record request from Mark Walker of The New York Times. The New York Times requests copies of the following information from: A year by year breakdown of all the police department resisting arrest cases made during traffic stop from 2010 through the date of the search for responsive records. Please provide the data in spreadsheet format. The spreadsheet should include, but not be limited to, the following fields: Date of the stop, time of the stop, reason for the stop, outcome of the stop, race of the person who was stopped, age of the person who stopped, gender of the person who was stopped, charges (if any), name of the suspect (if arrested). I request a waiver of all fees for this request. Disclosure of the requested information to me is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in my commercial interest. There can be little doubt that The Times constitutes a requester "primarily engaged in disseminating information." 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II). There can also be little doubt that the requests relate to federal government activity; I am requesting expedited processing of this request because it concerns a matter of both urgency and of public concern. We understand that your office’s capacity may be impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak, response efforts and protests. Should that be the case, we would be happy to discuss potential streamlining or narrowing of our request, reasonable delays in processing this request, or other accommodations. Please feel free to contact us at the telephone number listed in the final paragraph of this letter; we look forward to working with you. The New York Times seeks all responsive records regardless of format, medium, or physical characteristics, and includes any attachments to these records The New York Times insists that your agency use the most up-to-date technologies to search for responsive information and take steps to ensure that the most complete repositories of information are searched. The New York Times is available to work with you to craft appropriate search terms. If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law. To ensure that this request is properly construed, that searches are conducted in an adequate but efficient manner, and that extraneous costs are not incurred, The New York Times welcomes an opportunity to discuss its request with you before you undertake your search or incur search or duplication costs. By working together at the outset, The New York Times and your agency can decrease the likelihood of costly and time-consuming litigation in the future. Where possible, please provide responsive material in electronic format by email or in PDF or TIF format on a USB drive. Please send any responsive material being sent by email. If it will accelerate the release of responsive records to The New York Times, please also provide responsive material on a rolling basis. Thank you for your consideration of this requ

Rita McCarthy Local 12 To Whom It May Concern: This office has requested copies of certified payrolls submitted by Harold Bros. on the Boston Arts Academy in the City of Boston. The original request was on January 8, 2021. On January 21, 2021 our office received excel spreadsheets as a response from the City Boston with some information but not copies of the certified payrolls. On January 25, 2021 this office responded to the City regarding the spreadsheets received and once again asked for copies of the certified payrolls originally requested on January 8, 2021. The City did not properly respond to our original request nor did they respond to our follow up email informing them that the spread sheets were not acceptable. On February 26, 2021 our office resubmitted a second request to the City for copies of the certified payrolls from Harold Bros. for work performed on the Boston Arts Academy. Once again the City responded with the same excel spread sheets and not copies of the certified payrolls. The City of Boston has either ignored, or is refusing to comply with this public records request. The Labor Management Office of Local 12 has submitted many requests to the City of Boston for copies of certified payrolls on many projects and has never had a problem. In the current matter regarding the Boston Arts Academy, the City appears to have refused to comply with providing public records that are submitted to them pursuant to M.G.L. ch149, s27b.There should be no confusion regarding the records this office is seeking. Our office is asking the Supervisor of Records to assist us and order the City of Boston to comply with our request for public records, the public records being copies of certified payrolls from Harold Bros. for work performed at the Boston Arts Academy. Should the City not have the records in their possession then we are asking your office to direct the City of Boston to either acquire, or direct this contractor to provide said records forthwith as soon as possible. Thank you for your assistance on this matter and please stay safe.

Sam Sam To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: Data stored in the inPursuit Record Management System pertaining to use of force incidents covering the dates 2012 to 2021. Specifically, I request the following fields: -Date/Time occurred -type of charge -criminal charge files -subject name - subject sex -subject race -subject age -subject date of birth - subject address - level of resistance (and the subfeilds) - subject armed with (and the subfeilds) - witness race - witness sex - officer rank - officer sex - officer age - officer duty status - officer level - address of incident - officer employee id - officer badge - resist arrest - weapons/physical force (and the subfeilds) We are also requesting any data dictionaries, code tables, or other types of manuals that define, in plain English, the meaning of the column headers in the data, and any codes, acronyms, abbreviations or other shorthand terms used for entries in the data. We are asking for an export of raw data, to the extent maintained in the departments databases. We do not expect the department to manually input or alter any information into the data for the purposes of fulfilling this request. Redactions: If a record contains both exempt and non-exempt information, the non-exempt information should still be provided: Because we are requesting data, each distinct type of information is separated into its own field (i.e. column), making it easy to redact exempt information en masse. Entitlement to Records as Data: We request these records in a machine-readable database or spreadsheet format — such as SQL, CSV, XML, JSON, Excel, or Access files — and not printed out, or converted to PDF files, or otherwise processed in a manner that would decrease the quality, quantity, or accessibility of the original information the records represent. We realize the information may be contained in multiple tables. We are not asking the department to join tables together for us, or to conduct any type of analysis on the data. We are merely asking for the department to export the raw data, as it exists in the department's inPursuit database, which should minimize the amount of programming necessary to fulfill our request. Additionally we are in possession of the inPursuit records management manual. As such, we are acutly aware of how and what data is stored by the Boston PD. All fields requested are part of this system, if the custodian has any trouble finding the record we are happy to assist by citing the section of the manual which outlines the procedure for data exportation. We can do the joining on our own, so long as each table contains the unique identifiers and primary keys necessary to join the tables together, and so long as we are provided the necessary documentation to ensure that we are accurately joining and analyzing the data. We are comfortable working with very large databases in many standard data formats. Upon request, we would be happy to provide a USB thumb drive or external hard drive to facilitate the release of these records. Other Provisions: If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $50. However, since this information is being sought for public research purposes, we request that any fees be waived because disclosure of the responsive records is squarely in the public interest and will make a significant contribution to the public's understanding of critical issues related to policing. If you deny any portion of this request, please cite the specific statute that you feel justifies each exemption, The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be g CiovO\

We are in the process of completing a national study on hate crime investigations, funded by the National Institute of Justice. We are obtaining the number of investigations law enforcement agencies investigated from January 1, 2018 to December 31, 2018, where there was an indicator of possible hate or bias motivation by an offender against an individual's or a group's race, religion, ethnic/national origin, gender, age, disability, or sexual orientation. According to the Massachusetts Crime database, the Boston Police conducted over 140 hate crime investigations in 2018. Would you be able to confirm that this number is accurate? Also, we have been following up with the officers who investigated these cases to gather additional information regarding the type of bias, the crime committed, whether there was an arrest, and de-identifying information about the victim and suspect. We understand, however, that this would be overly burdensome to agencies with a large number of cases, so for those agencies we are requesting redacted police reports to gather this information. Given the amount of cases your agency had in 2018, we would take a random sample of about 25 cases.
